texts.definition: Gameplay where players can easily suffer bad consequences for being inattentive at any given point.
markups: <style="Definition">Gameplay where players can easily suffer bad consequences for being inattentive at any given point.</style>

Many games are designed with the intent to make people be interesting in them while playing but this can take different forms. They can be said to have <style="CurrentLink">Attention Demanding Gameplay</style> when they put players in risk of losing or being penalized for being inattentive at any time, something that also often occurs in naturally evolve games.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Sports">Sports</link></style> which are playing against other people, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Soccer">Soccer</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ice%20Hockey">Ice Hockey</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tennis">Tennis</link></style>, have <style="CurrentLink">Attention Demanding Gameplay</style> since players need to keep continuous track of what other players are doing at all time (besides the ball or puck).

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Pinball%20Games">Pinball Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pinball%20Dreams">Pinball Dreams</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Star%20Trek:%20The%20Next%20Generation">Star Trek: The Next Generation</link></style> show how mechanical or computer-based games can have <style="CurrentLink">Attention Demanding Gameplay</style>, and this was all-prevailing in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Arcade%20Games">Arcade Games</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pac-Man">Pac-Man</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Space%20Invaders">Space Invaders</link></style>). More recent examples of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer%20Games">Computer Games</link></style> having <style="CurrentLink">Attention Demanding Gameplay</style> include <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:FPS%20Games">FPS Games</link></style> (e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike%20series">Counter-Strike series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style>) and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Multiplayer%20Online%20Battle%20Arena%20Games">Multiplayer Online Battle Arena Games</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/League%20of%20Legends">League of Legends</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/StarCraft%20series">StarCraft series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Defense%20of%20the%20Ancients%20series">Defense of the Ancients series</link></style>) since they require people to pay close attention to the actions of their opponents or enemies.

The primary ways of creating <style="CurrentLink">Attention Demanding Gameplay</style> revolve around time and attention. While <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style> quite easily can require players to pay attention to what is happening in the game, <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style> can also have <style="CurrentLink">Attention Demanding Gameplay</style> in that players need to spread their attention between several different things in the game. <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goals</link></style> is an example of a design solution that can be apply both to <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style> to create <style="CurrentLink">Attention Demanding Gameplay</style>.

<style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> to perform certain actions can force players to have to pay attention to these while they last (an archetypical use of <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> is together with <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style>) and <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style> form a solid foundation for the pattern since this allows events to occur independently of players' actions. However, neither <style="Link"><link="time-pressure">Time Pressure</link></style> nor <style="Link"><link="time-limited-game-instances">Time Limited Game Instances</link></style> do necessarily create <style="CurrentLink">Attention Demanding Gameplay</style> as the game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/4%20Minutes%20and%2033%20Seconds%20of%20Uniqueness">4 Minutes and 33 Seconds of Uniqueness</link></style> shows. The pattern <style="Link"><link="always-vulnerable">Always Vulnerable</link></style> covers the "extreme" version of <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style> where assets in a game can be in danger even when players are not playing.

Given <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Attention Demanding Gameplay</style> can easily be created using common patterns such as <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="maneuvering">Maneuvering</link></style>. More specialized instances can be created locally through <style="Link"><link="flanking-routes">Flanking Routes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stealing">Stealing</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="scripted-information-sequences">Scripted Information Sequences</link></style> naturally draw players' attention and can create <style="CurrentLink">Attention Demanding Gameplay</style> when used together with <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Show%20Must%20Go%20On">The Show Must Go On</link></style>.

Various ways can modify <style="CurrentLink">Attention Demanding Gameplay</style> once a design with it has been created. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Disruption%20of%20Focused%20Attention">Disruption of Focused Attention</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attention%20Swapping">Attention Swapping</link></style> (e.g. through providing multiple <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style>) makes it more difficult to maintain. ''Required'' <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attention%20Swapping">Attention Swapping</link></style> can create <style="CurrentLink">Attention Demanding Gameplay</style> on its own. In contrast, letting players interact with <style="Link"><link="god-fingers">God Fingers</link></style> as <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> can make it easier for players to quickly move between various actions they need to perform. Finally, simply modifying the <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> associated with the failure of having attention modifies the demand of being attentive.

<style="CurrentLink">Attention Demanding Gameplay</style> can be difficult to use together with <style="Link"><link="game-pauses">Game Pauses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="minimalized-social-weight">Minimalized Social Weight</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="ubiquitous-gameplay">Ubiquitous Gameplay</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Attention Demanding Gameplay</style> gives rise to, or increases, <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> in games since players must keep their focus on the gameplay at all times. Failure to do so and the resulting effects can create <style="Link"><link="fubar-enjoyment">FUBAR Enjoyment</link></style>. Not surprisingly, the pattern is not compatible with <style="Link"><link="lull-periods">Lull Periods</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="always-vulnerable">Always Vulnerable</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attention%20Swapping">Attention Swapping</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="flanking-routes">Flanking Routes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="guard">Guard</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="maneuvering">Maneuvering</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="scripted-information-sequences">Scripted Information Sequences</link></style> together with <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Show%20Must%20Go%20On">The Show Must Go On</link></style>
